history.content: Chem 1A has never had good reviews; whether it fits for you is however hard to tell since these reviews are often given by potential pre-med students (many of whom end up dropping).  High school chemistry is all anyone has had for intro chem courses, so that's not an issue.  Personally, I would take chem 4A if you wish to take an intro chem course- because it is geared for prospective chemistry majors, the assigned professors are usually better teachers and the labs/course material is more fun (note the labs never take the full time slotted).  I will say I may be a bit biased, since I personally love chemistry (and I enjoyed 4A a long time ago).

children.subject: I took Astro 7A to fulfill the requirement. My favorite things about the course were that it didn't have a lab (you can't really make a star in lab, and astro undergrads aren't expected to know how to use simulation software) and that it was pretty well run. The problem sets can take a bit of time, and I do remember spending up to 15 hours on at least one, but considering that it's the only workload the class has to offer, I feel it's fair. The course material is admittedly all over the place, and it definitely is a physics class (read: not just regurgitating random facts about celestial bodies), but I thought it was easier than Physics 7B (admittedly, I really like physics, so factor that into your evaluation of this comment). There's also Astro 7B, which I've heard is more interesting and doesn't require knowledge from 7A, so there's that, but that's also a physics class I believe.

history.content:
I am a rising Junior and would like to fulfill my natural science requirement in Fall 2018.

I have taken Physics 7A and 7B but do not consider myself particularly strong in Physics, so I thought I would take a Chemistry course for the natural science requirement.  Is Chemistry 1A the most reasonable alternative in terms of manageable workload and quality of teaching?  I have only taken high school chemistry before.  

Thanks in advance for any insight, suggestions.
history.subject: EECS Natural Science Requirement
